EquiLend D&A Daily Digest

July 1, 2025

ðŸ“ˆ Market Notes

As of today's analysis, specific aggregate market-level fee and utilization data is being compiled and will be featured in upcoming reports. Today's focus is on security and sector-level trends.

ðŸ”¥ Major Headlines & What Our Data Shows

GLOBAL MARKETS: Equities Approach Highs, But Data Reveals Underlying Caution

A "risk-on" mood prevails as trade and geopolitical tensions appear to ease. However, our data shows investors are not uniformly bullish, with significant short positions being built in specific names.

Data: Borrowing in O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) has surged, with shares on loan up 3,581.81% month-over-month. European carrier Wizz Air (WIZZ) shows 18.68% short interest, while French payments firm Worldline (WLN FP) maintains a high 64.75% utilization, suggesting targeted hedging against the rally.

CENTRAL BANKS: Policy Speculation Drives Targeted Shorts

With the ECB's Forum underway and a major bill advancing in the U.S. Senate, investors are placing distinct bets on policy-sensitive securities.

Data: In Health Care, Summit Therapeutics (SMMT) shows 40.01% short interest with 95.87% utilization. Recursion Pharmaceuticals (RXRX) also displays high short interest (37.19%) and a steep borrowing cost of 1,416.84 bps. Conversely, a one-day decline of 24,500 borrowed shares in the First Trust North American Energy Infrastructure Fund (EMLP) suggests a rapid unwind of trades tied to the U.S. legislative agenda.

UK AUTOMOTIVE: Tariff Relief Not Yet Easing Short Pressure

A new, lower 10% tariff on UK car exports to the U.S. is now in effect, but short sellers appear unconvinced of an immediate positive impact for all players.

Data: Aston Martin Lagonda (AML LN) continues to experience intense borrowing pressure, with 97.97% utilization and an elevated borrow cost of 1,041.49 bps. The persistence of this short position indicates the market is in a "wait-and-see" mode regarding the tangible benefits of the new trade landscape.

ðŸ’¡ Key Takeaways

  • The Federal Reserve's commitment to data-dependency, combined with a historically inverted yield curve, appears to be prompting divergent positioning in fixed income. Our data suggests a potential rotation into short-duration government debt and out of high-yield credit, signaling concerns over credit risk and economic growth.
  • Global risk sentiment is being influenced by conflicting macro forces. While geopolitical escalations are fueling defensive positioning in areas like cybersecurity, positive economic news from China is causing a rapid unwind of short positions in large-cap Chinese technology firms.
  • Unexpectedly persistent inflation in the Eurozone is creating uncertainty for the ECB's rate path. This is reflected in securities lending data, which shows increased borrowing in European banking stocks, suggesting some investors are hedging against potential headwinds for the sector.
